text: SHADI MARTINI: I admire the US.

You know, the
values, the freedoms,

the diversity always
made me feel like--

you know, if you're an
immigrant, you're a foreigner,

you have an accent, if your
skin is different shades,
you would always fit in.
People will accept you.
I saw it as a tolerant society.

I saw it as a country that
offered a very good education
and future to my kids.

So I saw this as the perfect
place for my kids and myself.

I was hoping when I
come into United States,

I would have a peaceful life
without any consideration

about the racist,
about my religion.

I always held the United
States up to its great ideals--

freedom of religion, freedom of
speech, economic opportunities.

When I arrived here, I
felt like I was in heaven.

I can live the way I
want, practice my religion
and freedom of speech.

I can say whatever,
just the way I want.

[inaudible] I was viewed
through a religious lens,

through nationality,
country of origin,
the headscarf I wear on my head.

Now, it's falling short
living up to those standards
or those ideals.
